intro: Trophaeum pentaphyllum, commonly known as the five-leafed bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, blue to violet flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 centimeters and has hairy, opposite leaves. Its flowers bloom in late summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its ornamental value and limited distribution, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens.
